tdd_start: ^Built an elegant editor. Called it Inky.

c-0: ^test.js is empty. test.ink â€” one line.

tdd_17: ^"Cannot use Right-to-Left languages with Inky properly."

c-0: ^For one person. A workaround is a toll.

tdd_20: ^Someone writes: the syntax is thought LTR.
^The divert is neutral, not LTR. Missing classifier, not flaw.

c-0: ^Bidi experts don't use Ink. Ink users don't know bidi.

tdd_fix: ^Three chars per transition. Ace untouched. Ink untouched.
tdd_lesson: ^doesn't catch bugs. TDD makes bugs catchable.
^Write the test first because you care about the people who'll use it.
tt_intro: ^Back to 2016. This time â€” with Agile.
^You land in 2016. Inky was just built.
^You carry knowledge from the future. 8 years of failure.
^You're going to convince a small, brilliant team to work differently.
^I need to talk to you about process.
tt_pitch: ^The team looks at you with skepticism.
^'Process? We're three people. We don't need process.'
^'We built 80 Days without Scrum. Built Sorcery without sprints.'
^You're right. But let's try an experiment.
tt_bomb: ^'8 years? What are you talking about?'
^'Every one who opens Inky will see reversed arrows and wandering periods.'
^'And they won't file a bug. They'll just leave.'
^'So why won't we just fix it then?'
^'Because you won't know it's broken. Because you have no tests.'
tt_experiment: ^'Here's the deal: one sprint. Two weeks. With TDD.'
^'If after two weeks you feel it's a waste â€” we stop.'
tt_sprint0: ^Sprint 0 isn't a real sprint. It's preparation.
^Before you run, you need to know where.
^The backlog isn't a task list. It's a value list.
^As a Hebrew writer, I want the divert arrow to point the right way, so syntax doesn't confuse me.
^As an Arabic writer, I want periods at the left edge, so punctuation looks natural.
^As a developer, I want tests to run automatically, so I don't break things by accident.
tt_bureaucracy: ^'User Stories? We know what to build.'
^Right. You know what to build. In English.
^The Hebrew writer's story wasn't in your head in 2016.
^Not because you're bad. Because you write in English.
^User Stories force you to think from someone else's perspective.
^That's not bureaucracy. It's empathy with syntax.
tt_dod: ^When is something 'done'? When it works? When it compiles?
^2. New test for every new feature
^'If it works in Hebrew, it works in all RTL. If we didn't test â€” we won't know it's broken.'
tt_ci: ^CI isn't magic. It's a script that runs after every commit.
^That's it. One line. Runs every test you've written.
^If something breaks, you'll know in 30 seconds.
^'Sprint 0? Lists, definitions, setup? When do we code?'
tt_planning: ^Sprint Planning â€” the sprint planning meeting.
^Ask: what's the most valuable thing we can deliver in two weeks?

c-0: ^You chose the issue affecting the most people.
^That's the idea: team chooses, not the manager.

tt_standup_intro: ^Dev A: 'Yesterday researched Unicode Bidi. Today â€” first test. No blockers.'
^Dev B: 'Worked on plugins. Blocker: need to know if bidi affects the API.'
^'15 min every day? That's 5 hours/month of useless talk!'
tt_standup_waste: ^But 20% â€” someone is stuck and not saying.
^Or two people work on the same thing.
^Or someone discovered something that changes everything.
^5 hours of 'useless' saves 50 hours of duplicate work.
tt_standup_value: ^Dev B would have spent a week on an API ignoring bidi.
tt_tdd_red: ^TDD = three steps. First is the hardest:
^Write a test for a feature that doesn't exist yet.
^'We wrote a test that obviously fails. Waste of time.'
tt_why_red: ^Before one line of code, we have:
^â€” Contract. â€” Spec. â€” Success metric.
^A failing test isn't waste. It's design.
tt_tdd_green: ^Now â€” only now â€” write code.
^Rule: simplest code that makes the test pass.
tt_almost_same: ^Proof it works. Not just a feeling.
^Proof runs automatically. Forever. Break it â€” the test screams.
^Without TDD: write, test manually once, forget.
^With TDD: the test remembers for you.
tt_tdd_refactor: ^Step 3: improve code. The test protects you.
^â€” All RTL ranges (Syriac, Thaana, NKo, Samaritan, Mandaic)
^â€” bidify() â€” wraps runs in LRI/RLI/PDI
^â€” stripBidi() â€” strips markers before compilation
^'Red â†’ Green â†’ Refactor' took two hours.
^The x2 everyone fears? x2 on two hours = 4 hours.
tt_review: ^Review isn't slides. It's a live demo.
^Arrow right. Period left. Brackets in place.
^Review changed something. Team saw value. Not theory. On screen.
tt_retro: ^'User Story forced me to think differently.'
^Without it â€” dogma. With it â€” your process.
tt_x2_math: ^'9 hours! Full day on meetings and tests!'
^x2 on small saves x10 on big.
tt_reputation: ^Egyptian writer opens Inky. Works. Blog: 'Inky supports RTL!'
^Iranian teacher teaches Ink. 5 Farsi projects on itch.io.
^Dev in Tel Aviv opens Inky. Writes a USB story. Doesn't close.
^Happy user brings two. Frustrated repels ten.
^TDD vs no-TDD isn't technical. It's a business choice.
tt_year_later: ^Value compounds. Pain compounds. The gap is exponential.
tt_final: ^Agile isn't a process. It's a culture of listening.
